page.title: 05Flora and Fauna
page.content: From Forty Foot Lane, there is access to Sharnbrook Summit, which is a nature reserve leased by the Bedfordshire Wildlife Trust, from British Rail. The railway cutting was excavated during the 1850's as part of the railway track linking Bedford with Leicester. The line was opened in 1857 and is still in use today. The tunnel baulk, provides a fine viewing point. The baulk supports a wide variety of plants including cowslips, common birds foot trefoil, oxe eye daisy, ribbed melilot,zigzag clover, wild liquorice and hairy violets. The adjacent cutting is famous for its colony of grey-mouse ear. The thickets of brambles, rose and hawthorn provide nesting sites for a wide variety of birds including, whinchats in some years. Uncommon butterflies such as Dark Green Fritillaries and rare moths
